segment.source: Add and Remove Drivers to an Offline Windows Image
segment.target: Add and Remove Drivers to an Offline Windows Image

segment.source: Add and Remove Drivers to an Offline Windows Image
segment.target: Add and Remove Drivers to an Offline Windows Image

segment.source: Add and Remove Drivers to an Offline Windows Image
segment.target: Add and Remove Drivers to an Offline Windows Image

segment.source: You can use the Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM) tool to install or remove driver (.inf) files in an offline Windows image.
segment.target: You can use the Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM) tool to install or remove driver (.inf) files in an offline Windows image.

segment.source: You can either apply an unattended answer file to a mounted .wim, .vhd, or .vhdx file, or you can add or remove the drivers directly by using the command prompt.
segment.target: You can either apply an unattended answer file to a mounted .wim, .vhd, or .vhdx file, or you can add or remove the drivers directly by using the command prompt.

segment.source: When you use DISM to install a device driver to an offline image, the device driver is added to the driver store in the offline image.
segment.target: When you use DISM to install a device driver to an offline image, the device driver is added to the driver store in the offline image.

segment.source: When the image is booted, Plug and Play (PnP) runs and associates the drivers in the store to the corresponding devices on the computer.
segment.target: When the image is booted, Plug and Play (PnP) runs and associates the drivers in the store to the corresponding devices on the computer.

segment.source: Note To add drivers to a Windows 10 image offline, you must use a technician computer running Windows 10, Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview, or Windows Preinstallation Environment (WinPE) for Windows 10.
segment.target: Note To add drivers to a Windows 10 image offline, you must use a technician computer running Windows 10, Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview, or Windows Preinstallation Environment (WinPE) for Windows 10.

segment.source: Driver signature verification may fail when you add a driver to a Windows 10 image offline from a technician computer running any other operating system.
segment.target: Driver signature verification may fail when you add a driver to a Windows 10 image offline from a technician computer running any other operating system.

segment.source: To add drivers to an offline image by using DISM
segment.target: To add drivers to an offline image by using DISM

segment.source: At an elevated command prompt, retrieve the name or index number for the image that you want to modify.
segment.target: At an elevated command prompt, retrieve the name or index number for the image that you want to modify.

segment.source: For example, type:
segment.target: For example, type:

segment.source: An index or name value is required for most operations that specify a WIM file.
segment.target: An index or name value is required for most operations that specify a WIM file.

segment.source: For a VHD file, you must specify .
segment.target: For a VHD file, you must specify .

segment.source: Mount the offline Windows image.
segment.target: Mount the offline Windows image.

segment.source: For example, type:
segment.target: For example, type:

segment.source: Add a driver to the image.
segment.target: Add a driver to the image.

segment.source: To install all of the drivers from a folder and all its subfolders, point to the folder and use the /Recurse option.
segment.target: To install all of the drivers from a folder and all its subfolders, point to the folder and use the /Recurse option.

segment.source: Warning While /Recurse can be handy, it's easy to bloat your image with it.
segment.target: Warning While /Recurse can be handy, it's easy to bloat your image with it.

segment.source: Some driver packages include multiple .inf driver packages, which often share payload files from the same folder.
segment.target: Some driver packages include multiple .inf driver packages, which often share payload files from the same folder.

segment.source: During installation, each .inf driver package is expanded into a separate folder, each with a copy of the payload files.
segment.target: During installation, each .inf driver package is expanded into a separate folder, each with a copy of the payload files.

segment.source: We've seen cases where a popular driver in a 900MB folder added 10GB to images when added with the /Recurse option.
segment.target: We've seen cases where a popular driver in a 900MB folder added 10GB to images when added with the /Recurse option.

segment.source: To install an unsigned driver, use /ForceUnsigned to override the requirement that drivers installed on X64-based computers must have a digital signature.
segment.target: To install an unsigned driver, use /ForceUnsigned to override the requirement that drivers installed on X64-based computers must have a digital signature.

segment.source: Review the list of third-party driver (.inf) files in the Windows image.
segment.target: Review the list of third-party driver (.inf) files in the Windows image.

segment.source: Drivers added to the Windows image are named Oem.inf.
segment.target: Drivers added to the Windows image are named Oem.inf.

segment.source: This is to guarantee unique naming for new drivers added to the computer.
segment.target: This is to guarantee unique naming for new drivers added to the computer.

segment.source: For example, the files MyDriver1.inf and MyDriver2.inf are renamed Oem0.inf and Oem1.inf.
segment.target: For example, the files MyDriver1.inf and MyDriver2.inf are renamed Oem0.inf and Oem1.inf.

segment.source: Commit the changes and unmount the image.
segment.target: Commit the changes and unmount the image.

segment.source: To remove drivers from an offline image by using DISM
segment.target: To remove drivers from an offline image by using DISM

segment.source: At an elevated command prompt, retrieve the name or index number for the image that you want to modify.
segment.target: At an elevated command prompt, retrieve the name or index number for the image that you want to modify.

segment.source: An index or name value is required for most operations that specify a WIM file.
segment.target: An index or name value is required for most operations that specify a WIM file.

segment.source: For a VHD file, you must specify .
segment.target: For a VHD file, you must specify .

segment.source: Mount the offline Windows image.
segment.target: Mount the offline Windows image.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: Remove a specific driver from the image.
segment.target: Remove a specific driver from the image.

segment.source: Multiple drivers can be removed on one command line.
segment.target: Multiple drivers can be removed on one command line.

segment.source: Warning
segment.target: Warning

segment.source: Removing a boot-critical driver package can make the offline Windows image unbootable.
segment.target: Removing a boot-critical driver package can make the offline Windows image unbootable.

segment.source: For more information, see DISM Driver Servicing Command-Line Options.
segment.target: For more information, see DISM Driver Servicing Command-Line Options.

segment.source: Commit the changes and unmount the image.
segment.target: Commit the changes and unmount the image.

segment.source: To add drivers to an offline Windows image by using an unattended answer file
segment.target: To add drivers to an offline Windows image by using an unattended answer file

segment.source: Locate the device driver .inf files that you intend to install on the Windows image.
segment.target: Locate the device driver .inf files that you intend to install on the Windows image.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: All drivers in the directory and subdirectories that are referenced in the answer file are added to the image.
segment.target: All drivers in the directory and subdirectories that are referenced in the answer file are added to the image.

segment.source: You should manage the answer file and these directories carefully to address concerns about increasing the size of the image with unnecessary driver packages.
segment.target: You should manage the answer file and these directories carefully to address concerns about increasing the size of the image with unnecessary driver packages.

segment.source: Use Windows System Image Manager (Windows SIM) to create an answer file that contains the paths to the device drivers that you intend to install.
segment.target: Use Windows System Image Manager (Windows SIM) to create an answer file that contains the paths to the device drivers that you intend to install.

segment.source: Add the Microsoft-Windows-PnpCustomizationsNonWinPE component to your answer file in the offlineServicing configuration pass.
segment.target: Add the Microsoft-Windows-PnpCustomizationsNonWinPE component to your answer file in the offlineServicing configuration pass.

segment.source: Expand the Microsoft-Windows-PnpCustomizationsNonWinPE node in the answer file.
segment.target: Expand the Microsoft-Windows-PnpCustomizationsNonWinPE node in the answer file.

segment.source: Right-click DevicePaths, and then select Insert New PathAndCredentials.
segment.target: Right-click DevicePaths, and then select Insert New PathAndCredentials.

segment.source: A new PathAndCredentials list item appears.
segment.target: A new PathAndCredentials list item appears.

segment.source: For each location that you intend to access, add a separate PathAndCredentials list item.
segment.target: For each location that you intend to access, add a separate PathAndCredentials list item.

segment.source: In the Microsoft-Windows-PnpCustomizationsNonWinPE component, specify the path to the device driver and the credentials that are used to access the file, if the file is on a network share.
segment.target: In the Microsoft-Windows-PnpCustomizationsNonWinPE component, specify the path to the device driver and the credentials that are used to access the file, if the file is on a network share.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: You can include multiple device driver paths by adding multiple PathAndCredentials list items.
segment.target: You can include multiple device driver paths by adding multiple PathAndCredentials list items.

segment.source: If you add multiple list items, you must increment the value of Key for each path.
segment.target: If you add multiple list items, you must increment the value of Key for each path.

segment.source: For example, you can add two separate driver paths where the value of Key for the first path is equal to 1 and the value of Key for the second path is equal to 2.
segment.target: For example, you can add two separate driver paths where the value of Key for the first path is equal to 1 and the value of Key for the second path is equal to 2.

segment.source: Save the answer file and exit Windows SIM.
segment.target: Save the answer file and exit Windows SIM.

segment.source: The answer file must resemble the following sample.
segment.target: The answer file must resemble the following sample.

segment.source: Mount the Windows image that you intend to install the drivers to by using DISM.
segment.target: Mount the Windows image that you intend to install the drivers to by using DISM.

segment.source: For example, type:
segment.target: For example, type:

segment.source: An index or name value is required for most operations that specify a WIM file.
segment.target: An index or name value is required for most operations that specify a WIM file.

segment.source: For a VHD file, you must specify .
segment.target: For a VHD file, you must specify .

segment.source: Use DISM to apply the answer file to the mounted Windows image.
segment.target: Use DISM to apply the answer file to the mounted Windows image.

segment.source: For example, type:
segment.target: For example, type:

segment.source: For more information about how to apply an answer file, see DISM Unattended Servicing Command-Line Options.
segment.target: For more information about how to apply an answer file, see DISM Unattended Servicing Command-Line Options.

segment.source: The .inf files referenced in the path in the answer file are added to the Windows image.
segment.target: The .inf files referenced in the path in the answer file are added to the Windows image.

segment.source: Review the list of third-party driver (.inf) files in the Windows image.
segment.target: Review the list of third-party driver (.inf) files in the Windows image.

segment.source: Drivers added to the Windows image are named Oem.inf.
segment.target: Drivers added to the Windows image are named Oem.inf.

segment.source: This is to guarantee that all new drivers that are added to the computer are uniquely named.
segment.target: This is to guarantee that all new drivers that are added to the computer are uniquely named.

segment.source: For example, the files MyDriver1.inf and MyDriver2.inf are renamed Oem0.inf and Oem1.inf.
segment.target: For example, the files MyDriver1.inf and MyDriver2.inf are renamed Oem0.inf and Oem1.inf.

segment.source: For example, type:
segment.target: For example, type:

segment.source: Unmount the .wim file and commit the changes.
segment.target: Unmount the .wim file and commit the changes.

segment.source: For example, type:
segment.target: For example, type:

segment.source: If you need drivers for WinPE to see the local hard disk drive or a network, you must use the windowsPE configuration pass of an answer file to add drivers to the WinPE driver store and to reflect boot-critical drivers required by WinPE.
segment.target: If you need drivers for WinPE to see the local hard disk drive or a network, you must use the windowsPE configuration pass of an answer file to add drivers to the WinPE driver store and to reflect boot-critical drivers required by WinPE.

segment.source: For more information, see Add Device Drivers to Windows During Windows Setup.
segment.target: For more information, see Add Device Drivers to Windows During Windows Setup.
